intro: Geophila scortechinii, commonly known as the narrow-leaf mountain ginger, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to Southeast Asia. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its slender, upright stems and small, opposite leaves. The plant produces clusters of white or pale yellow flowers with five petals, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in forest understories. Due to its ornamental value and ecological significance, it is sometimes cultivated in botanical gardens.
